construction and performance requirements and 
testing standards for marine equipment, which is 
adopted in accordance with Article 35(2) of the 
Directive;”, 

and 

(ii) by inserting after the definition of “importer” the following: 

together with

the resolutions and

by Regulation 2 of S.I. No. 580 of 2024) the following: 

“(b) 
 have the conformity assessment carried out, 
through a notified body, using one of the procedures 
referred to in Article 15(2)(a) or (b) of the Directive 
and the modules for conformity assessment set out in

Implementing Regulation,”, 

and 

(c) 

in Regulation 46 (as amended by Regulation 5 of S.I. No. 625 of 
2021), by inserting after paragraph (2) the following: 

“(3) Transitional periods shall be allowed for marine equipment, 
which is specified in the Commission Implementing 
Regulation referred to in Regulation 10(2)(b), and which is 
in compliance with the requirements for type-approval in 
force in the State before the date indicated in the

text_raw:
EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations amend the European Union (Marine Equipment) Regulations 
2017 (S.I. No. 177 of 2017), which give effect to Directive 2014/90/EU on 
marine equipment, known as the Marine Equipment Directive. 

The amendment replaces the reference to a particular Commission Implementing 
Regulation, in Regulation 10(2)(b), with a general reference to “the most 
recently adopted” Commission Implementing Regulation, to take account of the 
annual adoption by the European Commission of a new Implementing 
Regulation to update the list of items of marine equipment that have become 
subject to harmonised EU requirements pursuant to the Marine Equipment 
Directive. 

The amendment also adds a definition for the term “international instruments” 
to provide clarity as to its meaning; and re-introduces a reference to the 
transitional periods that are specified in the annual Commission Implementing 
Regulation, during which certain items of marine equipment can continue to be 
placed on the market and on board an Irish ship.
